title: Spice Trade History
description: Journey through the history of the spice trade that shaped the world!

questions.question: Which spice was once worth more than gold by weight?
questions.explanation: Saffron has historically been the world's most expensive spice by weight, sometimes exceeding the price of gold. It requires about 75,000 crocus flowers to produce one pound.

questions.question: Which group of islands was historically known as the 'Spice Islands'?
questions.explanation: The Maluku Islands (Moluccas) in present-day Indonesia were known as the Spice Islands because they were the original source of nutmeg, mace, and cloves.

questions.question: Which European nation first dominated the spice trade route around Africa to Asia?
questions.explanation: Portugal dominated the spice trade after Vasco da Gama reached India in 1498, establishing a maritime route around the Cape of Good Hope.

questions.question: What was Columbus actually searching for when he discovered the Americas in 1492?
options: A western route to the Spice Islands
questions.explanation: Columbus was seeking a western sea route to Asia and the Spice Islands. Instead, he reached the Americas, which he initially believed were part of Asia.

questions.question: Which spice was called 'black gold' in medieval Europe?
questions.explanation: Black pepper was so valuable in medieval Europe that it was used as currency, and peppercorns could be used to pay rent and taxes.

questions.question: The ancient Silk Road connected China to which region for trade, including spices?
questions.explanation: The Silk Road was a network of trade routes connecting China to the Mediterranean and Europe, facilitating the exchange of spices, silk, and other goods for centuries.

questions.question: Which Dutch company monopolized the spice trade in the 17th century?
questions.explanation: The Dutch East India Company (VOC), founded in 1602, became the most powerful trading company in history, monopolizing the spice trade from the Spice Islands.

questions.question: Cinnamon was originally harvested from trees native to which country?
questions.explanation: True cinnamon (Cinnamomum verum) is native to Sri Lanka (formerly Ceylon). The island was a major source of cinnamon for thousands of years.

questions.question: Which spice led to a territorial conflict between the Dutch and British known as the 'nutmeg wars'?
questions.explanation: The Dutch and British fought over the tiny nutmeg-producing Banda Islands. In 1667, the Dutch traded Manhattan to the British in exchange for control of Run Island, a nutmeg source.

questions.question: Which ancient civilization used spices extensively in their mummification process?
questions.explanation: Ancient Egyptians used cinnamon, cassia, and other spices in their mummification process, as well as for perfumes and medicines.

questions.question: Vanilla is native to which part of the world?
questions.explanation: Vanilla is native to Mexico and Central America. The Aztecs used it to flavor their chocolate drinks. Today, Madagascar is the largest producer.

questions.question: Which explorer's voyage around the world proved that the Spice Islands could be reached by sailing west?
questions.explanation: Ferdinand Magellan's expedition (1519-1522) was the first to circumnavigate the globe, proving the Spice Islands could be reached by sailing westward from Europe.

questions.question: Which city was the main European hub for the medieval spice trade?
questions.explanation: Venice dominated the medieval European spice trade as the gateway between Eastern trade routes and Western European markets, growing extremely wealthy as a result.

questions.question: What chili pepper did Columbus bring back from the Americas, mistakenly calling it 'pepper'?
questions.explanation: Columbus brought back Capsicum (chili peppers) from the Americas, calling them 'peppers' because of their spicy taste, though they are unrelated to black pepper (Piper nigrum).

questions.question: Which spice comes from the stigma of a crocus flower and requires hand-harvesting?
questions.explanation: Saffron comes from the stigma of the Crocus sativus flower. Each flower produces only three stigmas, which must be hand-picked, making it the world's most labor-intensive spice.
